markdownRemark.html:
1. Introduction

1.1. Moses:

- Advantage: Useful pre- and postprocessor
- Disadvantage: Hand-crafted and language dependent

1.2. Sentencepiece

- 2 algorithms: BPE and unigram
- Not language-dependent

2. SentencePiece overview

  • 4 main components:

    • Normalizer - normalize semantically equivalent Unicode characters into canonical forms
    • Trainer, Encoder, Decoder - as normal

3. Library Design

3.1 Lossless Tokenization

- Decoder(Encoder(text))= text 
    example: Encode("Hello world.") = Hello _wor ld . (no space between "world" and ".")

3.2 Effient subword training and segmentation

- BPE segmentation: Merged symbols are managed by a binary heap (priority queue)
    -> O(Nlog(N))
- Unigram segmentation: O(N)

3.3 Vocab id management

spm specifies the final size of vocab

3.4 Customizable character normalization

- Unicode standard Normalization Froms (NFC, NFKC) used widely in NLP

3.5 Self-contained models

3.6 Library API for on-the-fly processing

4. Experiments

  • Dataset: KFTT (440k, 1166, 1160 sentences)
  • Model: GNMT (Eng-Ja)
  • Compare to: Moses - English, Kytea - Ja
  • Metric : case-sensitive BLEU

frontmatter.title: SentencePiece: A simple and language independent subword tokenizer
